page.title: 14Farming - Dairy Farming
page.content: The block is predominately a dairy farming area. A typical family farm covers about 137 acres. The average herd will be 100 British Freisians. Most farmers breed their own replacement herd of heifers. Some farmers fatten up beast cattle but most sell cross bred calves at 1 month old. Cows calve once a year and spend 8 weeks dry each year before calving. On average each cow will give 24 ltrs of milk per day. His day starts when he rises at 5:30 to begin milking at 6:00. The average working day lasts 10.5 hours. The farmer generally does his own vetinary work unless the problem is serious. Half the land is grazing and the other half is used for silage with about 2 or 3 cuts taken and put in clamps. The farm is fully mechanised with mowing and milking machines, tractors & forage harvesters
